The **Tables of the Law** as they are widely known in English, or **Tablets of
Stone** , **Stone Tablets** , or **Tablets of Testimony** (in
[Hebrew](/wiki/Hebrew_language "Hebrew language"): לוחות הברית _Luchot HaBrit_
\- "the tablets [of] the covenant") in the [Hebrew Bible](/wiki/Hebrew_Bible
"Hebrew Bible"), were the two pieces of stone inscribed with the [Ten
Commandments](/wiki/Ten_Commandments "Ten Commandments") when
[Moses](/wiki/Moses "Moses") ascended [Mount Sinai](/wiki/Biblical_Mount_Sinai
"Biblical Mount Sinai") as written in the [Book of
Exodus](/wiki/Book_of_Exodus "Book of Exodus"). [Exodus
31:18](http://www.mechon-mamre.org/p/pt/pt0231.htm#18) refers to the tablets
as the "Tablets of (the) Testimony".

According to the Bible, there were two sets. The first, inscribed by God,
([Exodus
31:18](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Exodus+31%3A18&version=NIV))
were smashed by Moses when he was enraged by the sight of the [Children of
Israel](/wiki/Children_of_Israel "Children of Israel") worshipping a [golden
calf](/wiki/Golden_calf "Golden calf") ([Exodus
32:19](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Exodus+32%3A19&version=NIV))
and the second were later cut by Moses and rewritten by God. ([Exodus
34:1](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Exodus+34%3A1&version=NIV))

According to traditional teachings of [Judaism](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism") in
the [Talmud](/wiki/Talmud "Talmud"), they were made of blue
[sapphire](/wiki/Sapphire "Sapphire") stone as a symbolic reminder of the sky,
the heavens, and ultimately of God's [throne](/wiki/Throne "Throne"). Many
[Torah](/wiki/Torah "Torah") scholars, however, have opined that the Biblical
"_sapir_ " was, in fact, the [lapis lazuli](/wiki/Lapis_lazuli "Lapis lazuli")
(see [Exodus
24:10](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Exodus+24%3A10&version=NIV),
lapis lazuli is a possible alternate rendering of "sapphire" the stone
pavement under God's feet when the intention to craft the tablets of the
covenant is disclosed [Exodus
24:12](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Exodus+24%3A12&version=NIV)).
[1]

According to the bible, both the first shattered set and the second unbroken
set were stored in the [Ark of the Covenant](/wiki/Ark_of_the_Covenant "Ark of
the Covenant") (the _Aron Habrit_ in Hebrew).

## Appearance of the
tablets[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tablets_of_Stone&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Appearance of the tablets")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/The10Commandments.png/220px-
The10Commandments.png)](/wiki/File:The10Commandments.png)

[](/wiki/File:The10Commandments.png "Enlarge")

A popular image of the Tablets as rounded-off rectangles bears little
relationship with religious traditions about their appearance. In this case,
the [Ten Commandments](/wiki/Ten_Commandments "Ten Commandments") are
represented by the first ten letters of the [Hebrew
alphabet](/wiki/Hebrew_alphabet "Hebrew alphabet"), which in Hebrew usage may
be used [interchangeably with the numbers 1-10](/wiki/Gematria "Gematria").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Meister_der_Bibel_des_Patrice_L%C3%A9on_001.jpg/220px-
Meister_der_Bibel_des_Patrice_L%C3%A9on_001.jpg)](/wiki/File:Meister_der_Bibel_des_Patrice_L%C3%A9on_001.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Meister_der_Bibel_des_Patrice_L%C3%A9on_001.jpg "Enlarge")

Rectangular tablets passed down by the [Hand of God](/wiki/Hand_of_God_\(art\)
"Hand of God \(art\)") in the 10th century [Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine
"Byzantine") [Leo Bible](/wiki/Leo_Bible "Leo Bible").

In recent centuries the tablets have been popularly described and depicted as
round-topped rectangles but this has little basis in religious tradition.
According to Rabbinic tradition, they were rectangles, with sharp corners,[2]
and indeed they are so depicted in the 3rd century paintings at the [Dura-
Europos Synagogue](/wiki/Dura-Europos_Synagogue "Dura-Europos Synagogue") and
in Christian art throughout the 1st millennium,[3] drawing on Jewish
traditions of [iconography](/wiki/Iconography "Iconography").

The rounded tablets appear in the Middle Ages, following in size and shape
contemporary hinged [writing tablets](/wiki/Wax_tablet "Wax tablet") for
taking notes (with a stylus on a layer of wax on the insides). For
[Michelangelo](/wiki/Michelangelo "Michelangelo") and [Andrea
Mantegna](/wiki/Andrea_Mantegna "Andrea Mantegna") they still have sharp
corners (see gallery), and are about the size found in Rabbinic tradition.
Later artists such as [Rembrandt](/wiki/Rembrandt "Rembrandt") tended to
combine the rounded shape with the larger size. While, as mentioned above,
Rabbinic tradition teaches that the tablets were squared, according to some
authorities, the Rabbis themselves approved of rounded depictions of the
tablets in replicas so that the replicas would not exactly match the
historical tablets.[4]

According to the Talmud, the length and width of each of the Tablets was six
[Tefachim](/wiki/Biblical_and_Talmudic_units_of_measurement "Biblical and
Talmudic units of measurement"), and each was three Tefachim thick -
respectively roughly 20 and ten inches,[5] though they tend to be shown larger
in art. Also according to tradition, the words were not engraved on the
surface, but rather were bored fully through the stone.

## Content[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tablets_of_Stone&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Content")]

In [Jewish religious tradition](/wiki/Judaism "Judaism"), the arrangement of
the commandments on the two tablets is interpreted in different ways. Rabbi
[Hanina ben Gamaliel](/wiki/List_of_Jewish_leaders_in_the_Land_of_Israel "List
of Jewish leaders in the Land of Israel") said that each tablet contained five
commandments, "but the Sages say ten on one tablet and ten on the other".[6]
Because the commandments establish a covenant, it is likely that they were
duplicated on both tablets. This can be compared to diplomatic
[treaties](/wiki/Treaty "Treaty") of [Ancient Egypt](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt
"Ancient Egypt"), in which a copy was made for each party.[7] But the tablets
may have contained not only the Ten Commandments but also additional precepts
and words as can be inferred from the verses Exodus 31:18, Exodus 34:1, Exodus
34:27-28. [8]

## Christian
replicas[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Tablets_of_Stone&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Christian replicas")]

Replicas of the tablets, known as [tabots](/wiki/Tabot "Tabot") or sellats,
are a vital part of the practice of [Ethiopian Orthodox
Church](/wiki/Ethiopian_Orthodox_Church "Ethiopian Orthodox Church"), which
claims that the original Ark of the Covenant is kept in the [Church of Our
Lady Mary of Zion](/wiki/Church_of_Our_Lady_Mary_of_Zion "Church of Our Lady
Mary of Zion") in [Axum](/wiki/Axum "Axum").[9]

The [Quran](/wiki/Quran "Quran") states that
_[tablets](/wiki/Tablet_\(religious\) "Tablet \(religious\)")_ were given to
[Moses](/wiki/Moses "Moses"), without quoting their contents explicitly:

    "And We ordained laws for him in the tablets in all matters, both commanding and explaining all things, (and said): 'Take and hold these with firmness, and enjoin thy people to hold fast by the best in the precepts: soon shall I show you the homes of the wicked,- (How they lie desolate).'" ([Quran](/wiki/Quran "Quran") [7:145](http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2002.02.0006%3Asura%3D7%3Averse%3D145))

These tablets are not broken in the Quran, but picked up later:

    "When [Moses](/wiki/Moses "Moses") came back to his people, angry and grieved, he said: 'Evil it is that ye have done in my place in my absence: did ye make haste to bring on the judgment of your Lord?' He put down the tablets, seized his brother by (the hair of) his head, and dragged him to him..." ([Quran](/wiki/Quran "Quran") [7:150](http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2002.02.0006%3Asura%3D7%3Averse%3D150)). "When the anger of [Moses](/wiki/Moses "Moses") was appeased, he took up the tablets: in the writing thereon was guidance and Mercy for such as fear their Lord." ([Quran](/wiki/Quran "Quran") [7:154](http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A2002.02.0006%3Asura%3D7%3Averse%3D154)).

qa.question: where are the two tablets of the ten commandments
qa.answer: ['The Tables of the Law as they are widely known in English, or Tablets of Stone, Stone Tablets, or Tablets of Testimony (in Hebrew: לוחות הברית Luchot HaBrit - "the tablets [of] the covenant")']
